contents.name: Figure RA.11 - RA Trouble Ticket
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.11 - RA Trouble Ticket

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Revenue Assurance Trouble Ticket ABE entities represent trouble tickets opened to resolve one or several causes (for example, Revenue Assurance Violations) that resulted in a Revenue Assurance KPI not meeting a Revenue Assurance Objective....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.11 - RA Trouble Ticket

ownedComment.body: Revenue Assurance Trouble Ticket ABE entities represent trouble tickets opened to resolve one or several causes (for example, Revenue Assurance Violations) that resulted in a Revenue Assurance KPI not meeting a Revenue Assurance Objective. Just as the model for controls and KPIs were similar, so are the models for RevenueAssuranceViolations and RevenueAssuranceTroubleTickets as shown in figure RA.11. There are two primary differences in the two models. First, a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is a type of TroubleTicket, which in turn is a type of BusinessInteraction. Therefore, the TroubleTicket inherits the same characteristics from BusinessInteraction as RevenueAssuranceViolation. Second, RevenueAssurranceViolations may be used in the derivation of a RevenueAssuranceKPI, which then may trigger a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket. For example, if more than “X” number of customers are not billed in a given billing cycle for services used, a trouble ticket is generated. This KPI is a sum of all the “true” parameters that were RevenueAssuranceControl parameter values representing a single unbilled customer. For this reason, the RevenueAssuranceViolationSpec may influence the creation of a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket via the specification’s association with a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicketSpec.

contents.name: Figure RA.03 - RA Parameter
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.03 - RA Parameter

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: The Revenue Assurance Control ABE defines rules that represent the logical definition of comparisons, validations, reconciliation’s, and so forth performed on entities, such as bills and call detail records (CDRs), to identify Revenue Assurance Violations. Simple rules can be stated using RevenueAssuranceObjectives; complex rules can be stated using PolicySets. Revenue Assurance KPI ABE models KPIs and Revenue Assurance Objectives whose violation trigger Revenue Assurance Trouble Tickets....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.03 - RA Parameter

ownedComment.body: The Revenue Assurance Control ABE defines rules that represent the logical definition of comparisons, validations, reconciliation’s, and so forth performed on entities, such as bills and call detail records (CDRs), to identify Revenue Assurance Violations. Simple rules can be stated using RevenueAssuranceObjectives; complex rules can be stated using PolicySets. Revenue Assurance KPI ABE models KPIs and Revenue Assurance Objectives whose violation trigger Revenue Assurance Trouble Tickets. Revenue Assurance Controls and Revenue Assurance KPIs serve similar purposes; violating thresholds or other rules associated with them create a discrepancy. In the case of a Revenue Assurance Control, the discrepancy is a Revenue Assurance Violation; in the case of a Revenue Assurance KPI the discrepancy is a Revenue Assurance Trouble Ticket. The identification of discrepancies begins with calculating a value for the control or KPI. An example of a simple rule expressed as a RevenueAssuranceObjectiive is a value (true [1] or false [0]) determined every day for each customer to be billed that day, that has services and associated usage, but the usage has not been rated and will therefore not appear on the bill. The values are calculated by a defined algorithm, at a specified frequency, and are valid for a certain period of time. In this case the parameter is a RevenueAssuranceControl. If the value is true a RevenueAssuranceViolation is created that identifies the customer as not being billed for services used. An example of a complex rule expressed as a PolicySet is billing for a higher or lower bandwidth than provided on a circuit. This rule requires an “or” condition not available via RevenueAssuranceObjective. From a SID perspective controls and KPIs can be viewed as types of RevenueAssuranceParameters as shown in the following Figure. The following Figure also reveals that RevenueAssuranceControls can also serve as a base for RevenueAssuranceKPIs. For example, if a control exceeds a certain threshold, the action taken may be that the control is considered to be a KPI also.

contents.name: Figure RA.04 - RA Objective
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.04 - RA Objective

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Thresholds for the RevenueAssuranceParameters are characteristics of RevenueAssuranceObjectives as shown in the following Figure....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.04 - RA Objective

ownedComment.body: Thresholds for the RevenueAssuranceParameters are characteristics of RevenueAssuranceObjectives as shown in the following Figure. At times the simple rules defined by the attributes of RevenueAssuranceObjectives are not sufficient to determine if a discrepancy should be created based on the RevenueAssuranceParameterValue. In these cases, the rules would be defined by a PolicySet, which could be a PolicyRule or a PolicyGroup.

contents.name: Figure RA.07 - RA Consequence
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.07 - RA Consequence

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: In the complex rule example, where a bill was generated for higher or lower bandwidth than provided, there would be a complex condition composed as “IF BilledBandwidth > ProvidedBandwidth” “OR” “IF BilledBandwidth< ProvidedBandwidth”. These three attributes would be derived using a derivation algorithm defined in an existing subclass (ProdOfferPricePolicyVariable) of PolicyVariable. The action would be composed as “SET BandwidthBilledError to true”....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.07 - RA Consequence

ownedComment.body: In the complex rule example, where a bill was generated for higher or lower bandwidth than provided, there would be a complex condition composed as “IF BilledBandwidth > ProvidedBandwidth” “OR” “IF BilledBandwidth< ProvidedBandwidth”. These three attributes would be derived using a derivation algorithm defined in an existing subclass (ProdOfferPricePolicyVariable) of PolicyVariable. The action would be composed as “SET BandwidthBilledError to true”. See GB922 Common Domain section Policy ABE for detail. If the RevenueAssurranceObjective is not met then a consequence results as shown in figure RA.07. The RevenueAssuranceConsequence is characterized by a prescribedAction attribute. This simple attribute may not be sufficient to specify the consequence. If so, then the association to PolicyAction allows for a more complex action to be specified. For example, …Note that the prescribed action may also result in the creation of a RevenueAssuranceViolation or a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket as shown in Figure RA.08. Additionally, parameters, objectives and consequences may be applicable, or not, at certain times. For example, if objectives may be checked during the week, but not on the weekend; consequences may be less severe during the day than during the evening. These scenarios are handled by the RevenueAssuranceApplicability business entity, also shown in Figure RA.07.

contents.name: Figure RA.08 - RA Consequence Subclasses
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.08 - RA Consequence Subclasses

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Some type (modeled as a specification) of RevenueAssuranceViolation or some type (modeled as a specification) of RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is created if a RevenueAssuranceObjective is not met. This is based on whether the RevenueAssuranceParameter is a RevenueAssuranceControl or a RevenueAssuranceKPI. Figure RA.08 depicts RevenueAssuranceConsequence subclasses that trigger the creation of a RevenueAssuranceViolation or a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTIcket....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.08 - RA Consequence Subclasses

ownedComment.body: Some type (modeled as a specification) of RevenueAssuranceViolation or some type (modeled as a specification) of RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is created if a RevenueAssuranceObjective is not met. This is based on whether the RevenueAssuranceParameter is a RevenueAssuranceControl or a RevenueAssuranceKPI. Figure RA.08 depicts RevenueAssuranceConsequence subclasses that trigger the creation of a RevenueAssuranceViolation or a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTIcket. The actual RevenueAssuranceViolation or RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is created based on the specification related to the consequence. For example, in previous example, if a customer is not to be billed for services used, then the consequence is related to a RevenueAssuranceViolationSpec instance that classifies and characterizes the RevenueAssuanceViolation as one for unbilled customer services.

contents.name: Figure RA.09 - RA Violation
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.09 - RA Violation

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: The Revenue Assurance Violation ABE models’ discrepancies identified based on applying the rules defined by Revenue Assurance Control entities as described in the section on Revenue Assurance Controls....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.09 - RA Violation

ownedComment.body: The Revenue Assurance Violation ABE models’ discrepancies identified based on applying the rules defined by Revenue Assurance Control entities as described in the section on Revenue Assurance Controls. Figure RA.09 depicts how a RevenueAssuranceParameterValue that does not meet a RevenueAssuranceObjective results in a RevenueAssuranceConsequence. The consequence influences the selection of a RevenueAssuranceViolationSpec that results in a RevenueAssuranceViolation, which is also associated to the parameter value that triggered its creation. In the customer billing control, the value of true (1) means that the objective has not been met and results in a consequence named “Customer Service Not Billed”. The consequence is related to a RevenueAssuranceViolationSpec named “Discrepancy in Customer Services Billed”. The consequence describes the RevenueAssuranceViolation named “Customer X Billing Violation”, which is also related to the control value of true.

contents.name: Figure RA.12 - RA Parameters and Entities
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.12 - RA Parameters and Entities

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: The example presented up to this point references a business entity (ServiceUsage) for which the RevenueAssuranceParameter is calculated and the business entity instance (voice mail service for customer X). This implies that associations should be created from the parameter and parameter values to some other entities. The corresponding entities in the SID are RootBusinessEntityType and RootBusinessEntity....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.12 - RA Parameters and Entities

ownedComment.body: The example presented up to this point references a business entity (ServiceUsage) for which the RevenueAssuranceParameter is calculated and the business entity instance (voice mail service for customer X). This implies that associations should be created from the parameter and parameter values to some other entities. The corresponding entities in the SID are RootBusinessEntityType and RootBusinessEntity. A RootEntityType represents each occurrence of a business entity within the SID. For example, Customer, Service, Product, Service Usage are all instances of RootEntityType. The RevenueAssuranceParameter is associated with this entity as shown in Figure RA.12. In the example the “service billed” instance of parameter would be related to the “ServiceUsage” instance of RootEntityType. A RootEntity represents each occurrence of a business entity instance in the SID. In the example, the “1” instance of parameter value would be related to the ServiceUsage instance of Customer X’s voice mail usage. This association puts the parameter value into context.

contents.name: Figure RA.13 - RA Action
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.13 - RA Action

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Revenue Assurance Action/Response ABE entities represent the result of reconciling Revenue Assurance Trouble Tickets by initiating and performing a series of one or more activities. Revenue Assurance Action/Response ABE entities also model the root cause for Revenue Assurance Trouble Tickets based on rules that trigger root cause analysis....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.13 - RA Action

ownedComment.body: Revenue Assurance Action/Response ABE entities represent the result of reconciling Revenue Assurance Trouble Tickets by initiating and performing a series of one or more activities. Revenue Assurance Action/Response ABE entities also model the root cause for Revenue Assurance Trouble Tickets based on rules that trigger root cause analysis. The actions taken as a result of a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket being created are shown in Figure RA.13. Both the RevenueAssuranceActionSpec and the RevenueAssuranceAction entities inherit from existing activity entities that are part of the Project ABE in the Common Business Entities domain. RevenueAssuranceActionSpec and RevenueAssuranceAction represent an application of the EntitySpecification/Entity pattern used throughout the SID.

contents.name: Figure RA.14 - RA Action and TroubleTickets
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.14 - RA Action and TroubleTickets

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: <Note>Note that there is no explicit association shown between RevenueAssuranceActionSpec and RevenueAssuranceAction. Since RevenueAssuranceActivitySpec is a subclass of ActivitySpec and RevenueAssuranceAction is a subclass of Activitythe the association between ActivitySpec and Activity is inherited.</Note>...

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.14 - RA Action and TroubleTickets

ownedComment.body: <Note>Note that there is no explicit association shown between RevenueAssuranceActionSpec and RevenueAssuranceAction. Since RevenueAssuranceActivitySpec is a subclass of ActivitySpec and RevenueAssuranceAction is a subclass of Activitythe the association between ActivitySpec and Activity is inherited.</Note> The set of actions that may be performed to resolve a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket are modeled using the association between a RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicketSpec and RevenueAssuranceActionSpec. The association is shown in Figure RA.14. The RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicketSpec enables one or more RevenueAssuranceActionSpecs to be selected for which instances of RevenueAssuranceAction are created and associated to the applicable RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket. In the service usage example, the types of activities may include reviewing the customer account, checking the rating software, requesting a bug fix, close out the trouble ticket, and so forth.

contents.name: Figure RA.15 - RA Action and Response
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.15 - RA Action and Response

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Once the RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is resolved, or during the course of taking one or more actions, a RevenueAssuranceResponse may be created. Figure RA.15 depicts the model for RevenueAssuranceResponseSpec and RevenueAssuranceResponse....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.15 - RA Action and Response

ownedComment.body: Once the RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is resolved, or during the course of taking one or more actions, a RevenueAssuranceResponse may be created. Figure RA.15 depicts the model for RevenueAssuranceResponseSpec and RevenueAssuranceResponse. The RevenueAssuranceRepsonseSpec represents the different types of responses that can be created as part of a RevenueAssuranceAction. The type of responses is governed by the association between RevenueAssuranceActionSpec and RevenueAssuranceResponseSpec. The RevenueAssuranceResponseSpec describes the invariant characteristics of a RevenueAssuranceResponse. The response is a subclass of BusinessInteraction, and as such, inherits the characteristics of BusinessInteraction, including the ability to relate one response to another.

contents.name: Figure RA.16 - RA Trouble Ticket Root Cause
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.16 - RA Trouble Ticket Root Cause

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: As the RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is being investigated or after it is closed, a root cause for it and other trouble tickets may be found. The root causes can be created as an instance of RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket and related, using the BusinessInteractionRelationship entity, to the associated RevenueAssuranceTroubleTIckets for which it is the root cause. This is shown in figure RA.16.

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.16 - RA Trouble Ticket Root Cause

ownedComment.body: As the RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket is being investigated or after it is closed, a root cause for it and other trouble tickets may be found. The root causes can be created as an instance of RevenueAssuranceTroubleTicket and related, using the BusinessInteractionRelationship entity, to the associated RevenueAssuranceTroubleTIckets for which it is the root cause. This is shown in figure RA.16.

contents.name: Figure RA.18 - RA Assessment Result
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.18 - RA Assessment Result

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: The outcome of an assessment is defined by the RevenueAssuranceAssessmentResult business entity as shown in Figure RA.18. A result may be a RevenueAssuranceRecommendation or may be an identified RevenueAssuranceTrend. A trend is defined by its associated RevenueAssuranceParmValues and a RevenueAssuranceParameter as shown in the figure. For example, a recommendation may be to expand the time period during with a KPI is applicable; a trend may show an increasing number of customers not billed over a month-long period.

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.18 - RA Assessment Result

ownedComment.body: The outcome of an assessment is defined by the RevenueAssuranceAssessmentResult business entity as shown in Figure RA.18. A result may be a RevenueAssuranceRecommendation or may be an identified RevenueAssuranceTrend. A trend is defined by its associated RevenueAssuranceParmValues and a RevenueAssuranceParameter as shown in the figure. For example, a recommendation may be to expand the time period during with a KPI is applicable; a trend may show an increasing number of customers not billed over a month-long period.

contents.name: Figure RA.17 - RA Assessment
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.17 - RA Assessment

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Revenue Assurance Assessment ABE entities measure the effectiveness of Revenue Assurance Controls, Revenue Assurance Objectives, and Revenue Assurance KPIs. Revenue Assurance Assessment ABE entities include recommendations of refining controls, objectives, and KPIs....

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.17 - RA Assessment

ownedComment.body: Revenue Assurance Assessment ABE entities measure the effectiveness of Revenue Assurance Controls, Revenue Assurance Objectives, and Revenue Assurance KPIs. Revenue Assurance Assessment ABE entities include recommendations of refining controls, objectives, and KPIs. The RevenueAssuranceAssessement entity and its related entities support periodic assessments of a Revenue Assurance program as shown in Figure RA.17. One or more individuals and/or organizations (SID Party entity) playing a PartyRole, such as employee, can be involved in an assessment as shown in the figure. A RevenueAssuranceAssessment may target a number of different aspects of a Revenue Assurance program, such as KPIs, objective, consequences, and applicability. The RevenueAssuranceAssessmentItem enables this. Additionally, one or more KPIs, objectives, consequences, and/or applicability can be associated with a single item as shown in the figure. Both RevenueAssuranceAssessment and RevenueAssuranceAssessmentItem are characterized by a basic set of attributes which include a description, date started, and date completed.

contents.name: Figure RA.05 - RA and Policy Rule
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.05 - RA and Policy Rule

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: A PolicyGroup is a collection of rules used to define a related set of PolicyRules or other PolicyGroups. The PolicyRule entity acts as the heart of the Policy model and is shown in Figure RA.05. The rule is triggered by an event and comprised of one or more PolicyConditions and one or more PolicyActions. If a PolicyCondition(s) is met then one or more PolicyActions result. The PolicyRule is characterized further by a PolicyRuleSpec.

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.05 - RA and Policy Rule

ownedComment.body: A PolicyGroup is a collection of rules used to define a related set of PolicyRules or other PolicyGroups. The PolicyRule entity acts as the heart of the Policy model and is shown in Figure RA.05. The rule is triggered by an event and comprised of one or more PolicyConditions and one or more PolicyActions. If a PolicyCondition(s) is met then one or more PolicyActions result. The PolicyRule is characterized further by a PolicyRuleSpec.

contents.name: Figure RA.06 - RA and Policy Statement
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.06 - RA and Policy Statement

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: Each PolicyCondition and PolicyAction is defined by a PolicyStatement. A PolicyStatement is structured like a conventional “IF” statement, with a variable, operator, and value.

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.06 - RA and Policy Statement

ownedComment.body: Each PolicyCondition and PolicyAction is defined by a PolicyStatement. A PolicyStatement is structured like a conventional “IF” statement, with a variable, operator, and value.

contents.name: Figure RA.10 - RA and Business Interaction
contents.publish:qualifiedname: SID Models::Enterprise Domain::Enterprise Risk ABE::Revenue Assurance ABE::_ Revenue Assurance Addendum Figures::Figure RA.10 - RA and Business Interaction

publish:property.name: Description
publish:property.publish:value: A RevenueAssuranceViolation is a type of Notification, which in turn is a type of BusinessInteraction. As such it inherits a number of characteristics from BusinessInteraction, such as the date, description, status, and association with Location and association with PartyRole, for example, to whom the violation is assigned. Figure RA.10 shows the key entities that make up the BusinessInteraction ABE. Addendum Common Domain section Business Interaction ABE fully describes the BusinessInteraction ABE.

publish:property.name: Name
publish:property.publish:value: Figure RA.10 - RA and Business Interaction

ownedComment.body: A RevenueAssuranceViolation is a type of Notification, which in turn is a type of BusinessInteraction. As such it inherits a number of characteristics from BusinessInteraction, such as the date, description, status, and association with Location and association with PartyRole, for example, to whom the violation is assigned. Figure RA.10 shows the key entities that make up the BusinessInteraction ABE. Addendum Common Domain section Business Interaction ABE fully describes the BusinessInteraction ABE.
